group.label: E0 Complete these facility specific questions before continuing.

input.label: E0:01a What type of cold chain equipment is used in the store?
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Answers to this question switch later indicators on and off.

select1.label: A. Freezer room(s) and/or cold room(s) are used for storing vaccine?
B. Freezers and/or refrigerators are used for storing vaccine?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Including solar refrigerators.

select1.label: C. Freezer room(s), cold room(s), freezers or refrigerators are used for freezing icepacks or cooling cool water packs?
select1.hint: Select 'Yes' if there is equipment in the store used exclusively for freezing or cooling icepacks. Ignore fridge/freezers with icepack compartments or freezer rooms/cold rooms that are also used to store vaccine.

input.label: E0:02a Where are vaccines and diluents, syringes and safety boxes stored?
input.hint: Guidance Notes : It is common for syringes and safety boxes to be stored in separate buildings either in the vaccine store compound, or elsewhere - these sites and buildings need to be checked.

select1.label: A. Only vaccines are stored. The facility is not responsible for syringes and safety boxes?
select1.hint: Syringes and safety boxes may enter the immunization supply chain at a lower level than the primary store if they are received direct from the manufacturer or from another government department or agency. These products will always be stored at lowest delivery and health facility levels.

select1.label: B. Vaccine storage and dry storage in the same building?
C. Vaccine storage and dry storage in separate buildings on the same site?
D. Vaccine storage and dry storage on separate sites?

input.label: E0:03a What type of equipment is used to deliver and/or collect vaccine at this store?

select1.label: A. Cold boxes, vaccine carriers and/or other passive containers?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Other passive containers' includes insulated roll containers or palletized containers. These may be used at primary and sub-national levels.

select1.label: B. Refrigerated vehicles?

input.label: E0:04a What organization is responsible for vehicle operations at this store?
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Enter all options that apply. 'Vehicle' includes motorcycles, cars, trucks, boats and aircraft.

select1.label: A. Government agency
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : ' Guidance Notes : 'Transport' means any type of vehicle, including motorcycles, cars, trucks, boats and aircraft.

select1.label: B. Parastatal, PPP or 3PL contractor
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : PPP = public-private partnership. 3PL= third party logistics contractor.

select1.label: C. There is no official transport at this store
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Official' transport is one or both of A and B

input.label: E0:05a Specify all transport types used for vaccine delivery or collection at this level.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : List all transport types: government-operated, parastatal or private.

select1.label: A. Motorcycles
B. Cars, vans, trucks, refrigerated trucks and other road vehicles
C. Aircraft
D. Railway
E. Boat
F. Other

group.label: E1 - Pre-shipment and arrival procedures ensure that every shipment from the vaccine manufacturer reaches the receiving store in satisfactory condition and with correct paperwork.

input.label: E1:01a How are vaccines supplied to this primary store? [Select at least one option].
input.hint: Answer all sub-questions. There can be more than one answer = 'Y'. If vaccine is received direct from the manufacturer at more than one store, each of these stores should be assessed as a primary store.

select1.label: A. Via a UN source (e.g. UNICEF-SD or PAHO)?
B. From a regional distribution warehouse?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Regional distribution warehouses serving a group of countries may be a future development.

select1.label: C. Direct from international manufacturer(s)
D. Neighbouring country donations or transfers
select1.hint: Neighbouring country donations or transfers' covers the situation where a country in the region has excess vaccine with a short expiry date. To avoid unnecessary wastage this may be transferred to another country for a supplementary immunization activity or even for routine use.

select1.label: E. Direct from in-country manufacturer(s)
E1:02a Does the local VAR form include all the key procedures from UNICEF VAR Parts I to VII?
select1.hint: For international suppliers see UNICEF-SD guidance note: The UNICEF vaccine arrival report: Guidelines for completion - 2007 (This will be hyperlinked to the final version of the tool). For in-country manufacturers, the layout of the VAR should reflect local delivery arrangements, but should retain the key checking procedures on the UNICEF VAR.

input.label: E1:03a Assess vaccine arrival reports (VARs) received during the review period:
input.hint: Due to differences between vaccines in temperature sensitivity and packaging, only one type of vaccine should be recorded on each VAR. Therefore in the case of combined deliveries, a separate VAR should be completed for each vaccine in the shipment. For deliveries of DTP-HepB+Hib, one VAR should be used for DTP-HepB and another VAR for the lyophilized Hib, again due to differences in temperature sensitivity and packaging.

input.label: A. How many individual vaccine arrivals have there been?
input.hint: Diluent and droppers must be detailed on the same VAR as the vaccines with which they have been shipped.

input.label: B. There should be a VAR accompanying each individual vaccine. Record the number of VARs that were actually received.
input.hint: In the event of short shipment (quantity received does not match quantity on packing list) of vaccine, diluents or droppers, where the quantity that was short-shipped is delivered at a later date, separate VARs must be completed for each delivery.

input.label: C. Record how many of these received VARs were completed correctly by the 'Inspection Supervisor'.
input.hint: Inspection Supervisor' is the term used in the UNICEF VAR. 'Completed correctly' means that the UNICEF VAR Part III to Part VII, or local equivalent, must have been completed in full. The VAR and related documents (e.g. pre-shipment advice, lot release etc) should be filed together.

input.label: E1:04a Of the individual vaccine arrivals entered in E1:03a:A:
A. How many were received in exposed or damaged condition?
input.hint: Exposed or damaged condition' in this context means that the accompanying shipping indicators showed evidence of exposure to excessive heat or cold (UNICEF VAR Part V), and/or that the shipment was physically damaged (UNICEF VAR Part VI).

input.label: B. How many of these exposed or damaged arrivals were correctly followed up with the supplier within 14 days of receipt?
input.hint: Correctly followed up' means that the supplier was formally contacted and that arrangements were made to test or replace the vaccine. If all shipments were satisfactory, question B is automatically switched off.

input.label: E1:05a Of the individual vaccine arrivals entered in E1:Q3.A:
A. How many VARs reported incomplete accompanying documentation?
input.hint: Accompanying documentation' in this context must include the following: Airway Bill (or Waybill for local suppliers), Packing List, Invoice and Lot Release Certificate from the NRA in the country of origin (UNICEF VAR Part IV). Omission of any of these items indicates that the paperwork is incomplete.

input.label: B. How many of these incompletely documented arrivals were followed up within 14 days of receipt?
input.hint: Guidance Notes : 'Followed up' means that the supplier was formally contacted and that the missing paperwork was supplied.

input.label: E1:06a If any vaccines come from an international source, assess international lot release procedures during the review period.
input.hint: Lot release procedures: The quality of the vaccines must be assured by the National Regulatory Authority (NRA) of the manufacturing country. This NRA must license the product and release it on a lot by lot basis; in addition, the NRA must ensure on-going regulatory oversight through regular inspections of Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) and monitoring of Adverse Events Following Immunization (AEFIs).

input.label: A. How many individual vaccine lots were received during the review period?
input.hint: However, there are cases where a vaccine that is not used in the country of manufacture, will not be licensed in the country of origin. This is the case of the Scientific Opinion under Article 58 of the current legislation in Europe, procedure developed in collaboration with WHO. The evaluation performed by the European Medicines Agency (EMEA) is equivalent to that performed for products licensed for use in the European Community, but since the product will not be placed in the European market, they cannot issue a Marketing Authorization. EMEA will also evaluate lots and issue an equivalent to a Certificate of Batch Release. A procuring country can use a positive scientific opinion to license the vaccine through its own NRA.

input.label: B. For every lot received there should be a lot release certificate from the NRA in the country of origin, or an EMEA lot evaluation. Record the number actually received.
input.hint: If the procuring country does not have an NRA, or if its NRA is not competent enough to analyze licensing dossiers, it can still be assured of the quality of the vaccine if this has been WHO pre-qualified (even if the vaccine is not procured through UN Agencies) or licensed by a fully functional NRA or has a positive EMEA's Scientific Opinion. (Source: WHO/QSS)

input.label: E1:07a If any vaccines come from a local manufacturer, assess local manufacturer lot release procedures used for the release of vaccine lots during the review period:
A. How many individual vaccine lots were received during the review period?
B. There should be a lot release certificate from the local NRA for every lot received. Record the number actually received.
E1:08a If any vaccines have been donated or transferred from another country, assess lot release certificates for dontated and transferred vaccines during the review period.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Inter-country donations and transfers shoud be treated just like any other vaccine arrival. Lot release certificates are required for quality assurance purposes.

input.label: A. How many individual donated or transferred vaccine lots were received during the review period?
B. There should be an original lot release certificate for every lot received. Record the number actually received.
E1:09a If any vaccines come from an international source, checklist for working arrangements with customs and/or the NRA.

select1.label: A. Are the working arrangements with customs and/or the NRA satisfactory?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Satisfactory' means that there are clear channels of communication between customs and/or the NRA and the staff at the primary vaccine store.

select1.label: B. Does an SOP or MoU document specify working procedures with customs and/or the NRA?
select1.hint: An SOP is the best way to detail the responsibilities of the parties. There may also be a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU). However, an MoU is of no operational significance unless it describes the responsibilites of the parties.

select1.label: C. Are the procedures set out in the SOP or MoU thorough and complete?
select1.hint: Thorough and complete' means that the SOP or MoU sets out the responsibilities of the parties and agreed response times. Wherever possible, vaccine should be moved from the port of entry to the primary vaccine store within 24 hours of arrival.

select1.label: D. Are the agreed procedures followed?
E1:10a If any vaccines come from an international source, have customs staff received training in how to look after vaccine?
select1.hint: Delays include 1) flight delays; 2) the airport or border crossing cold room (if applicable) has failed or 3) transport to the primary store is delayed. Flight delays are ultimately the responsibility of the shipper but may effect availability of national staff to meet the delayed flight.

select1.label: E1:11a If any vaccines come from an international source. Is there a satisfactory written contingency plan in place in case of unexpected arrival delays?
E1:12a If any vaccines come from an international source, does removal of vaccine from the port of entry typically take more than 24 hours?
select1.hint: The relevant issue here is removal of the vaccine shipment from the port of entry. In some countries customs clearance takes place at the primary vaccine store and this process may take more than 24 hours.

input.label: E1:13a If international vaccine clearance takes more than 24 hours, Airport or border crossing cold room facility checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes : It is possible that vaccines could come by land.

select1.label: A. Is a +2°C to +8°C cold room available to hold vaccine before its removal to the primary store?
B. Is the cold room big enough to accommodate the largest anticipated vaccine shipment?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Airport cold rooms are likely to be large enough to accommodate vaccine shipments. Check capacity only if the cold room is small.

select1.label: C. Does the cold room have a continuous temperature recording device?
D. Does the cold room have a secure lock?
E. Is the temperature recorded at least twice every 24 hours and 7 days a week?

E1:14a If any vaccines come from an international source, are vaccines transported from the airport or border crossing to the primary store under temperature-controlled conditions (active or passive cooling)?
select1.hint: Temperature-controlled conditions' means that the vaccine is either transported in insulated shipping containers or in a refrigerated vehicle. If the former, it is essential that sufficient coolant remains in the shipping containers to last the journey. Vaccine shipping containers must include enough coolant to last a minimum of 48 hours at +43°C from the time of packing. If this time-temperature exposure is exceeded, the vaccine will potentially be at risk. Reference: Guidelines on the international packaging and shipping of vaccines. WHO/IVB/05.23.

select1.label: E1:15a Are syringes and safety boxes procured direct from a supplier or manufacturer?
select1.hint: Supply and distribution of consumables (syringes and safety boxes) are not always the direct responsibility of the immunization programme. However, these products are so important that the assessor should make every effort to investigate the supply chain. Answer 'Y' if consumables are received direct from the supplier or manufacturer.

input.label: E1:16a From where are supplies procured?
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Complete A to D if the answer to E1:15a is 'Y'.

select1.label: A. Via a UN source (e.g. UNICEF-SD or PAHO)?
B. From an international distribution warehouse?
C. Direct from international manufacturer(s) ?
D. Direct from in-country manufacturer(s) ?

input.label: E1:17a If any consumables come from an international source. Customs clearance checklist:
input.hint: Satisfactory' working arrangements may exist with customs staff on an informal basis, but this relies entirely on personal relationships. Ideally there should be a Memorandum of Understanding with Customs, setting out their responsibilities for clearing vaccine and looking after it correctly whilst it is at the port of entry.

select1.label: A. Are the working arrangements with customs satisfactory?
B. Does an SOP or MoU document specify working procedures with customs?
C.Are the procedures set out in the SOP or MoU thorough and complete?
D. Are agreed procedures followed?

input.label: E1:18a Assess procedures for receiving and checking consumables.
input.hint: As with vaccines, inspection and acceptance of the syringes, safety boxes and other consumables is a key step in the procurement process. There should be a properly administered arrival procedure.

select1.label: A. Is there a formal procedure for checking and recording arrival quantities?
B. Is there a formal procedure for checking and recording the condition of the consumables before acceptance?
select1.hint: Syringes have lot numbers and expiry dates which should be recorded and entered in the stock records in order to ensure correct EEFO handling throughout the in-country supply chain.

select1.label: C. Is there formal procedure for checking and recording lot numbers, expiry dates and manufacturing dates, where applicable?
select1.hint: Products such as FridgeTags have a maximum shelf life before activation - this affects their subsequent operating life. Consequently, they should be distributed and used in order of manufacturing date.

group.label: E2 All vaccines & diluents are stored within WHO-recommended temperature ranges.

select1.label: A. Has a systematic temperature monitoring study been carried out within the past 5 years?
B. Have the recommendations of this study been implemented?

input.label: E2:02a Freezer room and cold room temperature mapping checklist:
A. How many vaccine freezer rooms and cold rooms are there?
B. How many of these rooms have a fully documented temperature mapping study?
input.hint: Mapping should be repeated whenever changes are made which increase loading or affect air circulation, or when refrigeration equipment is replaced. Enquire whether mapping has been repeated and record in notes box.

select1.label: E2:03a Can the storekeeper(s) or health worker(s) give the correct storage temperature range for each of the vaccines on the schedule?
select1.hint: Knowledge of correct storage temperatures is vital. If the respondent gives any incorrect answers, score 'No'. Note also: 1) If s/he says that freeze-dried vaccines should be stored at -20°C record this as 'Yes'. Current WHO advice is to store these vaccines at +2° to + 8°C, but storage at -20°C will not damage these vaccines. 2) If s/he say that freeze-dried vaccines packed with diluents can be stored at -20°C, this answer MUST be scored as 'No'. 3) At service point level, it is correct to say that all vaccines can be stored at +2° to +8°C

select1.label: E2:04a Do the storekeeper(s) or health worker(s) know which vaccines on the schedule can be damaged by temperatures below 0°C?
select1.hint: It is essential that respondents know which of the vaccines should not be exposed to temperatures below 0°C. It is not important that they know the precise freezing temperature of each of these vaccines.

select1.label: E2:05a Has the storekeeper received classroom, or on-the-job, training in how to look after vaccines?
select1.hint: Training should cover the following minimum topics: 1) correct storage temperatures; 2) vaccines damaged by freezing; 3) vaccines which can be frozen; 4) vaccines which must be frozen; 5) VVM reading; 6) shake test; 7) temperature monitoring using the range of available devices; 8) storage of diluents; 9) how to arrange vaccines in cold rooms, freezer rooms, refrigerators and freezers; 10) icepack conditioning; 11) cold box/vaccine carrier packing.

select1.label: E2:07a If there is refrigeration equipment, Is there a complete set of manual temperature records for each and every cold room, freezer room, vaccine refrigerator and vaccine freezer throughout the review period?
select1.hint: This question applies all in health facilities with active refrigeration. It does not apply in health facilities where cold boxes or vaccine carriers are used to store vaccine temporarily. Manual records are necessary because this is the only way to be sure that temperatures are checked at least twice a day. 'Complete' means that there should be no missing' record sheets or electronic temperature traces and that the entire review period should be covered for each appliance.

select1.label: E2:08a If there are freezer rooms and/or cold rooms, Is there a complete set of temperature recorder discs and/or temperature logger printouts for each and every cold room and freezer room throughout the review period?
select1.hint: This question only applies in in health facilities with freezer rooms and/or cold rooms.

select1.label: E2:09a If refrigerated vehicles are used, Is there a complete set of temperature recorder traces and/or temperature logger printouts for each and every refrigerated vehicle throughout the review period?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : This question only applies in health facilities which use refrigerated vehicles.

select1.label: E2:10a If there are freezer rooms or cold rooms Does a random 7 day sample of temperature recorder traces/logger printouts for each cold room and freezer room agree with the matching manual temperature records? .
select1.hint: Select a random 7 day period for each appliance (not the same period for each). Check the twice daily temperature records against the corresponding times on the temperature trace. If the record is consistently within 2°C of the trace, this is acceptable. If there are significant discrepancies, especially if the temperature record is uniform and the trace is not, interview staff to establish the reasons.

select1.label: E2:11a If there is refrigeration equipment, Have temperature records been kept in a safe place for at least three years?
select1.hint: Countries should be encouraged to retain such records for tracing purposes. If records are not available for three years, review the records kept since the immunization programme adopted EVSM or EVM.

input.label: E2:12a If there is refrigeration equipment. Temperature review checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : There must be a written record of these reviews which identifies problems and records actions taken. A verbal assurance is not sufficient.

select1.label: A. Are temperature records formally reviewed at least once a month in order to identify temperature excursions and their causes?
select1.hint: Check whether records are reviewed and recorded. 'Excursions' are temperatures below +2°C or above +8°C for cold rooms and vaccine refrigerators, and above -5°C for freezer rooms and vaccine freezers.

select1.label: B. Have correct remedial actions been taken?
select1.hint: Interview the responsible person. Discuss and evaluate remedial actions taken.

select1.label: E2:13a If there are freezer rooms or cold rooms or refrigerated vehicle(s), is there a test calibration record to show that the cold rooms , freezer rooms and refrigerated vehicle (if used) are calibrated every 12 months?
select1.hint: Since calibration is a relatively complex and technical process it should be avoided wherever possible by choosing temperature monitoring devices which retain their calibration for extended periods, or which can be recalibrated automatically - e.g. by replacing a digital sensor. For service delivery level equipment calibration is impractical. However stem thermometers hold their calibration well and Fridge-tags are effectively calibrated for life (2-3 years). Bi-metallic dial thermometers loose calibration quite easily and are now excluded from PQS.

group.label: E3 Cold storage, dry storage and transport capacity is sufficient to accommodate all vaccines and supplies needed for the programme.

input.label: E3:01a If there is refrigeration equipment. Using data from the annual vaccine arrival schedule (primary level) or the annual vaccine delivery schedule (lower levels), establish whether the capacity of the +2°C to + 8°C vaccine store is sufficient over a one year cycle. Where relevant, include other products and supplementary vaccines.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Collect site data, then use the sidebar tool to perform these calculations.

input.label: A. Measure the net storage capacity of the +2°C to + 8°C store(s) in liters or m³.
B. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (1 month)
input.hint: Guidance Notes : The store capacity, taking account of utilization factor, is acceptable if it is greater than the maximum estimated volume of vaccine to be stored, +10%.

input.label: C. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (3 months)
D. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (6 months)
E. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume (including Pentavalent vaccine) in liters or m3, plus 10% (1 month)
F. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume (including Pentavalent vaccine) in liters or m3, plus 10% (3 months)
G. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume (including Pentavalent vaccine) in liters or m3, plus 10% (6 months)

E3:02a If there is refrigeration equipment. Using data from the annual vaccine arrival schedule (primary store) and the annual vaccine delivery schedule (lower levels), establish whether the capacity of the -20°C vaccine store is sufficient over a one year cycle. Where relevant, include other products and supplementary vaccines.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Collect site data, then use the sidebar tool to perform this calculation.

select1.label: A. Is any vaccine stored at -20°C in this store?

input.label: B. Measure the net storage capacity of the -20°C store(s) in litres or m³.
C. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (1 month)
input.hint: Guidance Notes : The store capacity, taking account of utilisation factor, is acceptable if it is greater than the maximum estimated volume of vaccine to be stored, +10%.

input.label: D. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (3 months)
input.hint: The store capacity, taking account of utilization factor, is acceptable if it is greater than the maximum estimated volume of vaccine to be stored, +10%.

input.label: E. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (6 months)

E3:03a If syringes and safety boxes (consumables) are stored at this level. Using data from the annual consumables arrival schedule (primary level) and the annual consumables delivery schedule (lower levels), establish whether the capacity of the dry store is sufficient over a one year cycle.
input.hint: Collect site data, then use the sidebar tool to perform this calculation. The dry store is often housed in a separate building and may be used to store other products in addition to EPI syringes and safety boxes, etc. judgment and enquiry is needed to establish whether capacity is sufficient. Ignore diluents in the volume calculation if the dry store is only used to store syringes and safety boxes. Diluents should be stored in the vaccine store itself.

input.label: A. Measure the net storage capacity of the dry store in liters or m³.
B. Enter maximum estimated diluent, syringe and safety box volumes liters or m³, plus 10%. (1 month)
input.hint: Guidance Notes : The store capacity, taking account of utilization factor, is acceptable if it is greater than the maximum estimated volume of vaccine to be stored, +10%.

input.label: C. Enter maximum estimated diluent, syringe and safety box volumes liters or m³, plus 10%. (3 months)
D. Enter maximum estimated diluent, syringe and safety box volumes liters or m³, plus 10%. (6 months)

select1.label: E3:04a Are supplementary vaccines and consumables kept in temporary store(s)?
select1.hint: Temporary facilities could be a commercial cold room or warehouse with space leased on a short-term basis. Or it could be a government facility - for example an airport cold room.

input.label: E3:05a If there are temporary stores, using data from the supplementary vaccine arrival schedule and the campaign vaccine delivery schedule, establish whether the capacity of the +2° to + 8°C vaccine store is sufficient over a one year cycle
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Collect site data, then use the sidebar tool to perform these calculations.

input.label: A. Measure the net storage capacity of the +2° to +8°C store(s) in liters or m³.
B. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (1 month)
input.hint: Guidance Notes : The store capacity, taking account of utilization factor, is acceptable if it is greater than the maximum estimated volume of vaccine to be stored, +10%.

input.label: C. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (3 months)
D. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (6 months)

E3:06a If there are temporary stores. Using data from the supplementary vaccine arrival schedule and the supplementary vaccine delivery schedule, establish whether the capacity of the -20°C vaccine store is sufficient over a one year cycle.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Collect site data, then use the sidebar tool to perform these calculations.

select1.label: A. Is any vaccine stored at -20°C in this store?

input.label: B. Measure the net storage capacity of the -20°C store(s) in liters or m³.
C. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (1 month)
input.hint: Guidance Notes : The store capacity, taking account of utilization factor, is acceptable if it is greater than the maximum estimated volume of vaccine to be stored, +10%.

input.label: D. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (3 months)
E. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (6 months)

E3:07a If there are temporary stores AND syringes and safety boxes (consumables) are stored at this level. Using data from the supplementary arrival schedule (primary level) and the supplementary vaccine delivery schedule (lower levels), establish whether the capacity of the dry store is sufficient over a one year cycle.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Collect site data, then use the sidebar tool to perform these calculations.

input.label: A. Measure the net storage capacity of the dry store in liters or m³.
B. Enter maximum estimated diluent, syringe and safety box volumes liters or m³, plus 10%.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : The store capacity, taking account of utilization factor, is acceptable if it is greater than the maximum estimated volume of vaccine to be stored, +10%.

input.label: C. Enter maximum estimated diluent, syringe and safety box volumes liters or m³, plus 10%. (1 month)
D. Enter maximum estimated diluent, syringe and safety box volumes liters or m³, plus 10%. (3 months)
E. Enter maximum estimated diluent, syringe and safety box volumes liters or m³, plus 10%. (6 months)
E3:08a Using data from the vaccine delivery schedule, establish whether transport capacity is sufficient to meet peak demand levels.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Collect site data, then use the sidebar tool to perform these calculations.

input.label: A. Measure the net storage capacity of the delivery vehicle(s) in liters or m³.
B. Enter peak delivery volume in liters or m³, plus 10%.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : The store capacity, taking account of utilization factor, is acceptable if it is greater than the maximum estimated volume of vaccine to be stored, +10%.

input.label: E3:09a If cold boxes or other passive containers are used. Using data from the vaccine delivery schedule or outreach session size data, establish whether coolant capacity is sufficient to meet maximum demand levels
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Collect site data, then use the sidebar tool to perform these calculations. There must be sufficient freezing or cooling capacity to produce an adequate flow of icepacks/chilled water.

select1.label: A. Is there sufficient freezing or cooling capacity to meet maximum demand? .
select1.hint: Icepack freezing or cooling may sometimes take place in another facility. If this is the case, the capacity of the other facility needs to be checked.

select1.label: B. Is there sufficient storage capacity for icepacks/chilled water packs storage to meet peak demand? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : 'Peak demand' is the maximum weight of icepacks/chilled water packs required in a day.

input.label: E3:10a If cold boxes or other passive containers are used. Using data from the vaccine delivery schedule, establish whether there are sufficient passive containers to meet maximum demand levels.
input.hint: Check total vaccine storage capacity of available passive containers and compare against delivery schedule. If containers are always supplied by the receiving store this question is not applicable here but must be assessed at the next level down in the supply chain.

select1.label: A. Does this store stock passive containers for delivery and/or collection?
select1.hint: Answer 'Y' if the store keeps a stock of passive containers. If delivery and collection dates are staggered, the same containers may be used for both purposes.

select1.label: B. Are there sufficient passive containers?
select1.hint: If some containers are in use, check the container inventory to establish how many there should be.

input.label: E3:11a If there is refrigeration equipment, vaccine store contingency planning checklist:
input.hint: Contingency plans are context-specific, but should include the following minimum elements: 1) Identify the major sources of risk (e.g. power failure, flood, earthquake, etc.). 2) Prepare a written contingency plan. 3) Post emergency contact details on the noticeboard in the vaccine store. 4) Staff must know that the universal safe storage temperature for ALL vaccines in an emergency is +2°C to +8°C.

select1.label: A. Is there a satisfactory SOP which sets out a contingency plan in the event of equipment failure or other emergency?
select1.hint: 5) Identify at least two alternative cold storage locations. Inspect them to make sure they are large enough, well-managed, and can maintain correct temperatures.

select1.label: B. Are emergency contact details posted in the vaccine store?
select1.hint: 6) Ensure that there is a written agreement with the selected emergency providers. If payment will be required, make sure that this can be funded.

select1.label: C. Do staff know what to do in the event of an emergency?
select1.hint: 7) Regularly rehearse the contingency plan with store staff and the emergency providers.

group.label: E4 Buildings, cold chain equipment and transport systems enable the vaccine and consumables supply chain to function well

input.label: E4:01a Vaccine store site checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes : A secure site requires a fenced compound with 24 hour guarding or surveillance.

select1.label: A. Can delivery vehicles easily reach the store(s)?
B. Is the site secure?

input.label: E4:02a Dry storage on a separate site. Dry store site checklist.

select1.label: A. Can delivery vehicles easily reach the store?
B. Is the site secure?

input.label: E4:03a Vaccine store or health facility building checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes : 'Vaccine store' in this context includes service point health facilities.

select1.label: A. Is the vaccine store building suitable for the climate?
select1.hint: Suitable' means one of the following: 1) Cold or temperate climates: Thermally insulated and heated. 2) Hot, wet climates: Naturally ventilated or air-conditioned. Well protected against rain penetration. 3) Hot, dry climates: Naturally ventilated or air-conditioned and/or passively protected against excessive heat build up. Protected against dust penetration.

select1.label: B. Is the roof free of leaks?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Roof leaks': Check for damp stains on ceilings.

select1.label: C. Are the external walls free of severe cracks or other major damage?
D. Are windows and external doors in good condition and secure (grilles and/or locks)? .
E. Are floors dry and reasonably level?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Reasonably level': The floor should not be visibly sloping and it should be smooth enough for small wheeled pallet trucks.

select1.label: F. Are there any fire extinguishers and have they been tested in the past 12 months?
select1.hint: Fire extinguishers should be tested and certified annually. There should be a label on each one showing the test date. Fire extinguishers are unlikely to be found in small health facilities, so enter 'n/a'.

select1.label: G. Is the electrical system satisfactory?
select1.hint: Satisfactory' means that wiring, circuit breakers, electrical sockets and light fittings are in good condition and securely fixed in place. All circuits should be properly earthed. In a full inspection the earthing of sockets can be checked with a ring main tester. If there are any doubts, a professional inspection should be carried out. Service point facilities may have no electricity. If this is the case, score 'n/a'.

select1.label: H. Is the drainage system working (both rainwater and foul drainage)?
J. Is the air-conditioning system working?
K. Is the heating system working?

input.label: E4:04a Separate dry store building. Building checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes : If there is more than one 'other' building, use this checklist and the notes box to cover them all.

select1.label: A. Is the dry store building suitable for the climate?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : 'Suitable' means one of the following: 1) Cold or temperate climates: Thermally insulated and heated. 2) Hot, wet climates: Naturally ventilated or air-conditioned. Well protected against rain penetration. 3) Hot, dry climates: Naturally ventilated or air-conditioned and/or passively protected against excessive heat build up. Protected against dust penetration.

select1.label: B. Is the roof leak-free?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Roof leaks': Check for damp stains on ceilings.

select1.label: C. Are the external walls free of severe cracks or other major damage?
D. Are windows and external doors in good condition and secure (grilles and/or locks)?
E. Are floors dry and reasonably level?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : 'Reasonably level': The floor should not be visibly sloping and it should be smooth enough for small wheeled pallet trucks.

select1.label: F. Are there any fire extinguishers and have been tested in the past 12 months?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Fire extinguishers should be tested and certified annually. There should be a label on each one showing the test date.

select1.label: G. Is the electrical system satisfactory?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Some health facilities may have no electricity.

select1.label: H. Is the drainage system working (both rainwater and foul drainage)?
J. Is the air-conditioning system working?
K. Is the heating system working?

input.label: E4:05a If there is refrigeration equipment Refrigeration equipment space checklist
input.hint: Ventilation requirements are climate-dependent and also depend on the type of refrigeration equipment installed. Refrigerators, freezers and cold/freezer rooms with monoblock cooling units discharge waste heat into the room and must be well ventilated. Split system cooling units discharge waste heat to the outside air, which avoids waste heat build up in the room. Natural ventilation works best if there is a low level air inlet and a high level outlet, preferably on opposite sides of the room. Note: Ventilation will only lower the room air temperature if the outside air is cooler than the inside air. During the daytime in hot dry climates, natural ventilation may actually increase the internal air temperature. In these climates night time ventilation is the most effective way to cool a room naturally.

select1.label: A. Is there sufficient space to maintain the equipment?
B. Is the room well ventilated?

input.label: E4:06a If cold boxes or other passive containers are used. Packing area checklist:
input.hint: It is rather difficult to assess packing area temperature as it depends on climate, building design building construction and time of inspection. In temperate climates there is unlikely to be a problem. In cold winter/temperate summer climates, the presence of a permanent heating system should ensure correct temperatures. In cold winter/hot summer (continental) climates heating is needed in winter and airconditioning is likely to be needed in summer. In hot humid climates indoor temperature is likely to be similar to the outdoor shade temperature unless there is airconditioning.

select1.label: A. Is the packing area close to the refrigeration equipment area?
B. Are the icepack freezers or chilled water pack coolers close to the packing area?
C. Is there sufficient lay out space for conditioning icepacks?
D. Are the empty containers stored in, or close to, the packing area?
E. Is there sufficient lay out space for packing vaccines into containers?
F. Is there sufficient space to store packed containers?
G. Are there working hand washing facilities in, or close to the packing area?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : 'Working' hand washing facilities means that at least cold water comes out of the tap.

select1.label: H. Can the temperature of the packing area be maintained between 15° and 25°C throughout the year?
J. Is the packing area protected against direct sunlight?

input.label: E4:07a If refrigerated vehicles are used. Packing area checklist:

select1.label: A. Is the packing area close to the refrigeration equipment area?
B. Are the delivery cartons or delivery crates stored in or close to the packing area?
C. Is there sufficient lay out space to assemble vaccine orders for packing into delivery cartons or delivery crates?
D. Can packed vaccines be loaded directly into the refrigerated vehicle?
E. Are there hand washing facilities in, or close to the packing area?
F. Can the temperature of the packing area be maintained between 15° and 25°C throughout the year?
G. Is the packing area protected against direct sunlight?
A. Is the office close to the vaccine storage area, packing area and loading bay?
B. Is the room large enough?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : A minimum of 7.5m² is recommended for a single storekeeper. The room needs to be larger if there is more than one person working in the office.

input.label: E4:09a Vaccine store: secondary storage space checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : This is not the same as the 'dry store' which is used for syringes and safety boxes.

select1.label: A. Is there enough storage space for diluents?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Diluents should be stored as close as possible to the vaccine.

select1.label: B. Is there enough storage space for packaging cartons or packaging crates?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Packaging should be kept close to the packing area.

select1.label: C. Is there enough storage space for cold boxes or passive containers?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Cold boxes should be kept close to the packing area.

select1.label: D. Is there enough storage space for consumables (spare parts, freeze indicators, stationary, etc.)?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Consumables need to be accessible, but it is not essential for them to be kept in the vaccine store itself.

select1.label: A. Does the dry store have well organized shelving, pallet standing or pallet racking?
B. Is there suitable mechanical handling equipment, if needed?
select1.hint: Suitable' mechanical handling equipment means pallet lifters in pallet standing stores and forklifts in high rise (pallet racking) stores. High rise shelving stores require safe and stable step ladders as a minimum.

input.label: E4:11a If there are freezer rooms and/or cold rooms. Cold room and freezer room checklist
input.hint: Ignore any equipment which is out-of-service for a legitimate reason - for example because it is being serviced or repaired. Check that any vaccine that was stored in the out-of-service equipment is being kept under safe conditions.

select1.label: A. Are all cold room and freezer room enclosures in good condition at time of inspection?
select1.hint: 'Good condition' means free of corrosion, with all panel joints properly sealed and no sign of excessive condensation or ice build-up on the face of the panels.

select1.label: B. Do all rooms have continuous temperature recorders?
C. Are all cold rooms and all freezer rooms fitted with dual refrigeration units?
D. Can doors be locked from the outside but freely opened from the inside?
E. Are all rooms fitted with sufficient good quality shelving?
select1.hint: Shelving should be strong enough to support the vaccine without sagging. Preferably it should be supplied by the cold room manufacturer.

select1.label: F. Cold climates only. Do cold rooms EITHER have low temperature protection OR are they located in a permanently heated room?
select1.hint: In the winter in cold climates there is a risk that the vaccine will freeze inside the cold room. To prevent this, the cold room should EITHER have a low temperature protection circuit OR the room in which the cold room is located should be permanently h

input.label: E4:12a If there are freezer rooms and/or cold rooms. Checklist for working in cold rooms and freezer rooms:
input.hint: See: User's handbook for vaccine cold rooms and freezer rooms. WHO/V&B/02.31. Without warm clothing it is unsafe to work in a cold room or freezer room for extended periods. Some tasks, such as physical stock counts, cannot be carried out without this protection.

select1.label: A. Is warm clothing available for cold store workers?
B. Have workers received training in safe working in cold stores?

input.label: E4:13a If there are refrigerators and/or freezers Vaccine freezer/refrigerator checklist.

select1.label: A. Do all vaccine freezers comply with the WHO specifications that were in force at date of purchase, including correct climate zone?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Check that the equipment's climate rating is correct for the site.

select1.label: B. Do all vaccine freezers have continuous temperature recorders?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Continuous temperature recording in freezers is only mandatory at primary store level.

select1.label: C. Do vaccine freezers have a working thermometer stored with the vaccine?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : All freezers should have a stem or dial thermometer.

select1.label: D. Do all vaccine refrigerators comply with the WHO specifications that were in force at date of purchase, including correct climate zone?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Check that the equipment's climate rating is correct for the site. PIS and PQS pre-qualified equipment should have a sticker to show the climate rating.

select1.label: E. Are all ice-lined refrigerators fitted with the correct vaccine storage baskets?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : ILRs must always be fitted with baskets so that vaccine does not come into contact with the bottom or walls of the unit because this can freeze vaccine.

select1.label: F. Do all vaccine refrigerators have continuous temperature recorders or refrigerator loggers or freeze indicators?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Continuous temperature recorders or refrigerator loggers (Fridge Tag type) are essential at primary level. Refrigerator loggers are desirable at SN, LD and SP levels.

select1.label: G. Do all vaccine refrigerators have a working thermometer stored with the vaccine?
H. Where applicable, are there sufficient reserve supplies of kerosene and/or gas?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : 'Sufficient' reserve supplies means at least one spare Jerry Can of kerosene or at least one spare full gas bottle.

select1.label: I. Where applicable, is kerosene or gas always available?
J. Cold climates only. Do vaccine refrigerators EITHER have low temperature protection OR are they located in a permanently heated room?

input.label: E4:14a If there is refrigeration equipment Inspect refrigeration equipment
A. How many refrigeration units are there (dual CR and FR units count as 2, refrigerators and freezers count as 1 each)?
B. How many of these are CFC-free?
E4:15a Standby generator.
input.hint: There should always be a standby generator at the primary store unless mains electricity is completely reliable and/or has a backup supply from a separate transformer. The same requirement applies at sub-national stores equipped with cold rooms. Generators are not required in small sub-national stores, lowest distribution level and service point stores where ice-lined refrigerators are used and there is at least 8 hours electricity per day. Generators are also not required where kerosene, gas or solar refrigerators are used or where a health facility uses cold boxes or vaccine carriers for storing vaccine.

select1.label: A. Is a generator required at this store?
B. Is a standby generator installed?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : If a generator is installed but is not required then the generator questions are switched off and need not be answered.

input.label: E4:16a If a generator is required and installed, standby generator checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : The sidebar tool can be used to help with these calculations.

select1.label: A. Is the generator in working order?
B. Can the generator start all the connected equipment in the vaccine store? .
select1.hint: The starting load for a refrigeration compressor is much higher than the running load. Ask for a demonstration to prove that the generator is able to cope with the combined starting load of all connected refrigeration units. Well-designed systems may have 'smart switching' which reduces the starting load by automatically phasing in the individual refrigeration units.

select1.label: C. Is the fuel tank large enough?
select1.hint: 72 hours continuous running is recommended, but this is context-dependent. If power cuts are short and/or fuel is readily available, a smaller capacity will be acceptable. The way to assess this is as follows: 1) Establish the longest power cut experienced during the review period. 2) Check the generator fuel consumption in liters per hour. 3) Check the capacity of the fuel tank. If tank capacity/consumption per hour is less than the longest power cut then the tank capacity is too small.

select1.label: D. Are there sufficient reserve supplies of fuel?
F. Is the generator in a secure compound?
E4:17a Is the voltage fluctuation sufficiently severe to require voltage regulation equipment?
select1.hint: Voltage regulation equipment on all refrigeration equipment is essential if voltage fluctuations exceed ±15%. Obtain information from an electrical engineer, or from the local supply company.

input.label: E4:18a If voltage regulation is required, voltage regulator checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : If there is no refrigeration equipment in a particular category - e.g. 'freezer room', enter 0 for the equipment number and 0 for the voltage regulator number.

input.label: A. How many freezer rooms are there?
B. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator?
input.hint: There may be a single central voltage regulator for the vaccine store or some sharing arrangement across multiple appliances. In this case score on the basis that every piece of equipment has a regulator and make a note in the comment box.

input.label: C. How many cold rooms are there?
D. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator of the correct type?
E. How many vaccine freezers and refrigerators are there?
F. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator of the correct type?
input.hint: Note: Solar refrigerators do not require voltage regulators. Absorption refrigerators require a different type of voltage regulator to those used for compression refrigerators. This needs to be checked during the inspection.

input.label: E4:19a Temperature alarm equipment checklist for freezer rooms and cold rooms.
input.hint: Ideally alarm systems should also have an external flashing light and/or alarm sounder so that security guards are alerted after working hours.

input.label: A. How many freezer rooms are there?
B. How many have functioning alarm systems?
C. How many cold rooms are there?
D. How many have functioning alarm systems?
E4:20a CONDITION: If there are refrigerators or freezers used for storing vaccine. Temperature alarm equipment checklist for vaccine freezers and refrigerators:
input.hint: Guidance Notes : This question is only applicable at primary level.

input.label: A. How many vaccine freezers and refrigerators are there?
B. How many have functioning alarm systems?

select1.label: E4:21a Are telecommunications links working?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Telecommunications links include telephone, internet and radio. At least one of these must be working well.

input.label: E4:22a If vaccine transport is directly operated by this store, General vehicle checklist (includes refrigerated vehicles).
input.hint: This checklist is written with road vehicles in mind. Some programmes may own and operate boats. If this situation is encountered, evaluate boats using this indicator. If transport is provided by a parastatal or private sector contractor try to inspect their vehicles, especially if refrigerated vehicles are used.

select1.label: A. Is every vehicle, for which the programme is responsible, in good mechanical condition?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Ignore vehicles that are scheduled for disposal.

select1.label: B. Does every vehicle, for which the programme is responsible, have its own user logbook?
C. Does every vehicle, for which the programme is responsible, have an up to date maintenance and service record (including a record of refrigeration unit servicing where applicable)?

input.label: E4:23a If refrigerated vehicles are used, Refrigerated vehicle checklist.
input.hint: Check that all vehicles in the fleet comply. Only score an indicator as 'Y' if all vehicles in the fleet have the feature. Most countries will only have refrigerated vehicles at primary level, but some may use them at sub-national level.

select1.label: A. Are vehicles and refrigeration units in good mechanical condition?
select1.hint: Refrigerated vehicles may not be directly operated by the vaccine store. However, they are such a critical element in the supply chain that their specification and condition must be checked, even if they are operated by a parastatal, PPP or 3PL.

select1.label: B. Do the refrigeration units maintain a temperature of +2°C to +8°C?
C. Are refrigerated bodies fully insulated with a certified standard of insulation (k value) (roof, walls and floor)?
select1.hint: The level of insulation required is climate and application dependent. But it should be stated in the vehicle specification.

select1.label: D. Are vehicles equipped with a self-sustained diesel refrigeration unit which can operate when the vehicle's engine is switched off?
E. Do refrigeration units have a standby electrical power system that can be plugged into a mains supply?
F. If any refrigerated compartment is more than 6 meters long, does it have an air ducting system?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Needed to equalize temperatures in long vehicles.

select1.label: G. Are vehicles equipped with a thermometer which can be read in the driver's cab?
H. Are vehicles equipped with a temperature recorder which can produce hard copy output?
A. If passive containers are used, do passive containers used at this level comply with WHO specifications?
select1.hint: Passive containers include cold boxes, vaccine carriers and palletiZed or roll containers. Identify products by using the PQS or PIS catalogue.

select1.label: B. If refrigerated vehicles are used, are the disposable cartons or reusable crates used to transport vaccine fit for purpose?
select1.hint: No standard set. Use judgment to assess quality. Most important is the way in which cartons or crates are packed and restrained.

group.label: E5 Maintenance of buildings, cold chain equipment and vehicles is satisfactory.

input.label: E5:01a Planned preventive maintenance checklist for buildings.
input.hint: This question is primarily about planned preventive maintenance (PPM). However, it is possible that the building is in good condition because it is being informally maintained. 01 : C covers this option.

select1.label: A. Is there a written multi-year planned preventive maintenance (PPM) programme?
select1.hint: An effective planned preventive maintenance programme for buildings should cover several years into the future and should set target dates for routine maintenance such as re-decoration, electrical safety inspections, fire-extinguisher maintenance, etc.

select1.label: B. Is there documentary evidence that the programme is being followed?
select1.hint: If the score to question A is 'N' then the score for Question B must also be 'N'. PPM activities should be monitored and recorded.

select1.label: C. Is there visual evidence that maintenance is taking place?
select1.hint: If an effective maintenance programme is in place, the building should be in good condition. Indicators of poor building maintenance include broken light bulbs, leaks and damp stains, blocked drains, flaking paintwork, etc. See answers to E4:04a.

input.label: E5:02a If there is refrigeration equipment, Planned preventive maintenance checklist for refrigeration equipment.
input.hint: In this context, 'Planned Preventive Maintenance (PPM)' is as set out in the cold chain equipment manufacturers' service manuals. Both the need for and the timing of PPM can be foreseen.

select1.label: A. Is there a written planned preventive maintenance (PPM) programme?
B. Is there documentary evidence that the programme is being followed?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : PPM should be recorded in a maintenance record book or worksheet.

select1.label: C. Is somebody assigned to carry out routine maintenance?
select1.hint: A permanent member of the facility staff must be formally assigned to carry out the tasks below. They should not be left to ancillary staff such as cleaners.

select1.label: D. Is there evidence that cold rooms/refrigerators/ freezers have recently been cleaned and defrosted?
select1.hint: Check for excessive ice accumulation on evaporator units or the inside lining. Ice accumulation or condensation along the panel joints in cold rooms and freezer rooms is a sign that panel joints are leaking or poorly designed.

select1.label: E. Is there evidence that kerosene refrigerator wicks have been trimmed and chimneys cleaned?
select1.hint: Frequent trimming and replacement of wicks in kerosene refrigerators is absolutely essential. Chimneys also need to be cleaned regularly, especially if kerosene quality is poor.

select1.label: F. Is there evidence that solar refrigerator battery electrolyte has been checked and solar panels cleaned?
select1.hint: Some flooded batteries are not sealed and require regular checking of electrolyte levels and topping up with battery acid. All solar panels should be cleaned from time to time to maintain efficiency. This is particularly important in dusty areas and in countries where there is snow.

select1.label: G. Are all solar panels completely unshaded by buildings, trees and overhead cables?
select1.hint: Shading seriously degrades solar panel performance. Shading problems can increase over the years following the original installation as trees grow, new buildings are built and new overhead cables are erected.

input.label: E5:03a If vaccine transport is directly operated by this store, transport maintenance and overhaul checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : This indicator only applies to government-operated vehicles - see E0:04a.A.

select1.label: A. Are vehicles maintained in accordance with the manufacturer's service manual?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : The maintenance regime in the manufacturer's service manual must be followed.

select1.label: B. Is there documentary evidence that the service manual is being followed?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Documentary evidence' may be a service log book or a stamp in the service manual supplied with the vehicle.

select1.label: C. Is there a written planned overhaul programme?
select1.hint: Overhaul' means the dismantling or replacement of major components, such as clutch linings, engines, transmissions, etc. The timing may vary between similar vehicles, but the need can be foreseen.

select1.label: D. Is there documentary evidence that the overhaul programme is being followed?

input.label: E5:04a If freezer room(s) or cold room(s) are used, Cold Room and Freezer Room refrigeration unit maintenance checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : If the cold room or freezer room has standby refrigeration units, count the number of units.

input.label: A. How many refrigeration units are there?
input.hint: Ignore equipment that has been officially decommissioned. Include any equipment that is temporarily switched off because it is not needed. Check that it operates.

input.label: B. How many were fully operational at the time of inspection?
input.hint: Check if the unit has been out of operation for more than 7 days. If so, record this in the notes box.

input.label: E5:05a If vaccine is stored at the facility AND there are refrigerators/freezers, vaccine refrigerator and vaccine freezer maintenance checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Include all vaccine refrigerators and freezers in the store, unless it is clear that broken units are genuinely being kept for spare parts or disposal.

input.label: A. How many vaccine refrigerators and freezers are there (all types, including solar)?
input.hint: Ignore equipment that has been officially decommissioned. Include any equipment that is temporarily switched off because it is not needed. Check that it operates.

input.label: B. How many were fully operational at the time of inspection?
input.hint: Check if the unit has been out of operation for more than 7 days. If so, record this in the notes box. With kerosene units, check that the burner has been assembled correctly.

input.label: E5:06a If there are dedicated icepack freezers/cool water pack coolers, maintenance checklist for freezer rooms, cold rooms, freezers and refrigerators only used for freezing icepacks or cooling cool water packs.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Include all units in the store unless it is clear that broken units are genuinely being kept for spare parts or disposal.

input.label: A. How many icepack/cool water pack units are there?
input.hint: Ignore equipment that has been officially decommissioned. Include any equipment that is temporarily switched off because it is not needed. Check that it operates.

input.label: B. How many were fully operational at the time of inspection?
input.hint: Check if the unit has been out of operation for more than 7 days. If so, record this in the notes box.

input.label: E5:07a If vaccine transport is directly operated by this store, transport availability checklist.
input.hint: As a general rule, under EVM recommendations, distribution vehicles should not be out of operation for more than 7 days. This question helps establish whether transport availability is high or low.

input.label: A. During the review period, how many vaccine collections, distributions or outreach immunization sessions were planned?
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Outreach immunization sessions' in this context means sessions that required a motorcycle, car or 4WD.

input.label: B. How many were cancelled or seriously delayed because of mechanical failure in the vehicle fleet?
input.hint: Cancelled' means that the distribution or immunization session did not occur during the planned working week. 'Vehicle' includes motorcycles, cars, 4WD, trucks and small boats. Air and rail links (if used) are assumed to be outside the programme's control.

group.label: E6 Stock management systems and procedures are effective.

select1.label: E6:01a Is a computerized stock control system in use?

input.label: E6:02a If computerized stock control is used, computerized stock control checklist.

select1.label: A. Is the software fit for purpose?
select1.hint: Fit for purpose' means that it can handle the full range of vaccines and commodities, has sufficient data capacity for the country's needs, and records the minimum data set listed in E6:04a and E6:05a.

select1.label: B. Is the software package supported by the software developer?
C. Is there up-to-date anti-virus software on the computer?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Anti-virus software is essential.

select1.label: D. Has the storekeeper received training in its use?
E. Is the computer suitable for its purpose and in working order?
F. Is the printer in working order and supplied with paper?
G. Is the computer equipment connected to the standby generator?
H. Are stock records printed out and filed as a permanent record at least once a month?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Paper records are needed as a backup and for quality assurance and review purposes.

select1.label: J: Are stock records backed up at least once a week?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Backup should be on a flash drive, secondary hard drive, CD/DVD or on a secure web-based backup site. Ideally the device should be kept off site.

select1.label: E6:03a Are all vaccine arrivals and vaccine dispatches recorded and stock balances updated within one working day of the transaction?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : The practice of batch processing arrival and delivery slips should be discouraged because it leads to out of date stock records.

input.label: E6:04a Do the stock records record the following information for all vaccines.

select1.label: A. Type of vaccine
B. Vaccine presentation (vial size)
C. Quantity received in doses
D. Vaccine manufacturer
E. Manufacturing batch or lot number
F. Expiry date of each vaccine batch
G. VVM status where applicable
H. Location in the store
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : A record of location in the store is essential at primary level and in larger sub-national stores. It is unnecessary in small sub-national stores and at health facility level.

input.label: E6:05a Do the stock records record the following information for all diluents that are packed separately from the vaccine to which they belong.

select1.label: A. Type of diluent
B. Diluent presentation (vial size)
C. Quantity received in doses
D. Diluent manufacturer
E. Manufacturing batch or lot number
F. Expiry date of each batch
G. Location in the store
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : A record of location in the store is essential at primary level and in larger sub-national stores. It is unnecessary in small sub-national stores and in health facilities

select1.label: E6:06a Does the programme prepare routine reports on internal vaccine distributions, and do these reports summarisze the details of each and every transaction?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : These should be monthly or quarterly depending upon the distribution frequency.

select1.label: E6:07a Are vaccine requisition forms used for ordering and receiving vaccine?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : See model SOP on requisitioning for guidance on good practice. Assess content of existing form(s) against the content of the model forms.

select1.label: E6:08a Is there an effective pre-delivery, or pre-collection, notification system in place?
select1.hint: Effective' means that the system is understood and used by the receiving stores and that deliveries or collections are reliably made on or near a day that has been arranged well in advance.

select1.label: E6:09a Do stock records and/or stock in hand demonstrate that vaccine is issued according to the 'earliest-expiry-first-out' (EEFO) principle?
select1.hint: Unless VVMs on later-dated stock show Stage 2 exposure, vaccines should always be issued in EEFO order. Health worker use of EEFO is covered by question E8:09. In PR, SN and LD stores, the stock records should contain the data needed to demonstrate compliance. Otherwise physically check the stock. In health facilities it may be easier to check the stock in hand.

select1.label: E6:10a Can the storekeeper make exceptions to the EEFO rule (e.g. because of VVM status)?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : If VVMs on later-dated stock show Stage 2 exposure whilst early-dated stock is still at Stage 1, the heat-exposed later-dated stock should generally be issued first.

select1.label: E6:11a Based on a representative sample, does the issuing store have a completed issue voucher for every delivery sent out during the review period?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Select a complete set of issue vouchers for one distribution period. There are unlikely to be any legitimate reasons for missing issue vouchers.

select1.label: E6:12a Do the vaccine quantities recorded on the sampled issue vouchers consistently match the relevant entries in the stock records?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Use the same sample as for E6:012a and check the issue vouchers against entries in the stock records. If the answer to E6:11a is 'N' score 'N'.

select1.label: E6:13a Does the issuing store have a completed arrival voucher for every delivery which took place during the review period?
select1.hint: Use judgment. If the review period has just ended, the arrival slip for recent deliveries may not yet have been received by the issuing store. There may be other legitimate reasons for missing forms. The important point is that the incoming goods must be checked and the form must be signed by the receiving store.

select1.label: E6:14a Does a representative sample of these completed arrival sections indicate that arrival checks were carried out correctly?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : As with temperature records, suspiciously 'correct' forms may conceal lax practices. If vaccines are put in quarantine for any reason, these vaccines should be ignored.

input.label: E6:15a If vaccine is stored at the facility, checklist for management of damaged or expired stock.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers.

select1.label: A. Is the stock control system designed to record vaccine and diluent wastage due to expiry, freezing or heat-exposure?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : If vaccine has to be discarded, any associated diluent must also be discarded. Failure to do this can lead to a stockpile of 'orphaned' diluent.

select1.label: B. If 'yes', do the records show that the system is being used?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : If the stock records show that there have been no losses during the review period, ask the storekeeper to confirm whether or not this is true.

select1.label: C. Do staff know that expired and damaged vaccine should be clearly labelled and stored out of the cold chain until final disposal?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Damaged vaccine must be clearly labelled and stored outside the cold chain to prevent it being issued in error.

select1.label: D. If 'yes', is there evidence that the procedure is followed?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Check that there is no damaged/expired vaccine in the store.

input.label: E6:16a If there is a functioning system for recording damaged or expired vaccine, select a freeze-sensitive vaccine. Establish how many doses have been discarded during the review period due to freezing or exposure to high temperature.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Carry out this check even if the storekeeper reports that no vaccine has been lost.

select1.label: A. Select a sample vaccine

input.label: B. Record number of doses of chosen vaccine issued during the review period.
C. Record number of doses of chosen vaccine discarded because of incorrect storage temperatures.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : This indicator can only be assessed if stock records are accurate, informative and truthful. If there is no method to record vaccine damage, the score is 0.

select1.label: E6:17a Are disposal facilities and procedures in accordance with WHO and/or national norms?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Refer to Guidelines for Safe Disposal of Unwanted Pharmaceuticals in and after Emergencies. WHO/EDM/PAR/99.2

select1.label: E6:18a Have records of discarded vaccine been kept for at least three years, or, if for a lesser period, since the immunization programme adopted the EVSM or EVM?
E6:19a Are internal reviews of the vaccine loss/damage records carried out at least twice a year?

input.label: E6:20a Assess stock level policy.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Use the stock records to assess whether the store held excessive and/or insufficient stock during the review period.

select1.label: A. Is a maximum stock level set for each vaccine and commodity?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A maximum stock level should be set to control over-stocking. Overstocking makes store management difficult and increases the risk of expiry.

select1.label: B. Is a reorder level set for each vaccine and commodity?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A reorder level is needed to take account of delivery lead-time so that safety stocks are not breached

select1.label: C. Is a safety stock level set for each vaccine and commodity?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A safety stock level needs to be set to reduce the risk of stockouts.

select1.label: D. During the review period, did the stock of each and every vaccine remain within its EVM recommended maximum?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: The EVM maximum recommended stock level for each vaccine is its defined maximum stock level plus 10%.

select1.label: E. During the review period, did the stock of each and every vaccine remain within its EVM recommended minimum?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: The EVM minimum recommended stock level for each vaccine is its defined safety stock level minus 10%.

input.label: E6:21a Check stockouts and related events during the review period.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: If no records are available, interview the storekeeper and make a judgment.

select1.label: A. Were vaccine stocks sufficient throughout the review period (no stockouts)?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A stockout occurs when the demand or requirement for an item cannot be fulfilled from the currently available inventory. It does not necessarily mean that there is zero stock. Cases may occur where there is a stockout, but this does not affect deliveries because a new vaccine arrival occurs before the next delivery has to be made. Question B covers this situation.

select1.label: B. Was the facility always able to supply all the lower level stores?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Deliveries to lower level stores are not applicable at health facility level.

input.label: E6:22a Physical inventory frequency checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers.

input.label: A. Enter the planned vaccine supply period, in months
B. Enter number of recorded physical counts of vaccine stocks carried out during the 12 month review period
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Primary stores should carry out a physical count at least 4 times a year. Lower level stores and health facilities should carry out a count at the time of each incoming delivery. The scoring logic assumes this frequency.

group.label: E6:23a If vaccine is stored at the facility, choose a sample freeze-dried vaccine and diluent

select1.label: E6:23a If vaccine is stored at the facility, choose a sample freeze-dried vaccine and diluent. Enter name.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: This question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers. The following checks are carried out.

input.label: A. Carry out a physical count of the sample vaccine. Enter number of doses counted.
B. Carry out a physical count of the sample diluent. Enter number of doses counted.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: 1) If the diluent count differs from the vaccine count by >±1% a 'Mismatch' message appears. Otherwise a 'Match' message appears.

input.label: C. Check stock records for sample vaccine. Enter number of doses recorded as currently in stock.
input.hint: 2) If the vaccine stock records = the vaccine count an '=' sign appears. If they are different, the warning 'Not =' appears.

input.label: D. Check stock records for sample diluent. Enter number of doses recorded as currently in stock.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: 3) If the diluent stock records = the diluent count an '=' sign appears. If they are different, the warning 'Not =' appears.

input.label: E. Scoring: Score 4 if stock count and records match exactly AND vaccine and diluent quantities are within 1% of one another (see results).
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Scoring: Ideally, the physical count and the stock records should always match at the end of the working day. However, there may be discrepancies during the day if the stock records are not updated immediately; check with the storekeeper. There are legitimate reasons why diluent quantities may differ from vaccine quantities. One of these is that vaccine manufacturers sometimes over-supply diluent. Therefore, if there is slightly more diluent than vaccine, there may be no problem. If there is much more, or much less diluent, than vaccine, there must be a problem. Use your judgment to adjust the score between 0 and 4.

input.label: E6:24a If consumables are held in this store, choose a sample consumable.

select1.label: A. Choose a sample consumable. Enter name.

input.label: B. Carry out a physical count of the sample consumable. Enter number of items counted:
C. Check stock records for sample consumable. Enter number of items recorded as currently in stock:
D. Scoring: Score 4 if stock count and records match exactly. Use your judgment to adjust the score between 4 and 0 for mismatches.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Scoring: Ideally, the physical count and the stock records should always match at the end of the working day. However, there may be discrepancies during the day if the stock records are not updated immediately; check with the storekeeper. There are legitimate reasons why diluent quantities may differ from vaccine quantities. One of these is that vaccine manufacturers sometimes over-supply diluent. Therefore, if there is slightly more diluent than vaccine, there may be no problem. If there is much more, or much less diluent, than vaccine, there must be a problem. Use your judgment to adjust the score between 0 and 4.

input.label: E6:25a If vaccine is stored at the facility, checklist for vaccine storage arrangements.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers.

select1.label: A. Is the vaccine stock secure?
B. Are contents labels fixed to all cold chain equipment indicating vaccine type, lot no. and expiry date?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check for labels on the lid of feezers and refrigerators, or on the edge of the shelves in freezer rooms and cold rooms. Score 'n/a' where labelling is not needed. Labels are not required at health facility level unless there are several refrigerators.

select1.label: C. Are vaccines correctly stored?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: No freeze-sensitive vaccines stored close to cold room evaporators, stored close to the ice lining in ILRs or stored close to the evaporator plate of service point refrigerators. No vaccines should be kept in the door shelves of domestic refrigerators.

select1.label: D. Is vaccine laid out in EEFO order, by type and by lot number?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Ask which vaccines of a particular type are going to be picked first and check whether these items have the shortest expiry date.

select1.label: E. Is the vaccine store clean, dry and pest-free?

input.label: E6:26a If consumables are held in this store, checklist for dry storage arrangements.

select1.label: A. Are dry goods secure?
B. Are dry goods correctly stored?
